children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Python code into C. Let's see what the Python code does. The code reads an integer n, then counts how many numbers from 1 to n are odd.

children.text:
Finally, it prints the ratio of the count to n.

First, the Python code uses next_int() to read n. In C, I can use scanf to read an integer. So I'll replace that part with scanf("%d", &n);. Then there's a loop from i in 0 to n-1. Wait, in the loop, the code checks if (i+1) is odd by using i+1 & 1.

children.text: Oh right, because in Python, the loop variable i runs from 0 to n-1. So adding 1 gives 1 to n. The equivalent in C would be a loop from 1 to n, maybe. Or adjust the loop variables accordingly.

children.text: Wait, in the Python code, for i in range(n): i starts at 0, so i+1 is 1, 2, ..., n. Then (i+1) & 1 checks if it's odd. So the loop can be for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) and then if (i % 2 == 1) then increment t. But in the original code, the loop runs n times. So i starts at 0, up to n-1. So i+1 is 1 to n. So in C, perhaps loop from 1 to n, and check each number. So either way works.

Now, the count t is initialized to 0. Then for each odd number, increment t.

Finally, print t divided by n. But in Python, t and n are integers. So t/n would be a float. For example, if n is 5 and t is 3, then 3/5 is 0.6.

In C, if I do t / n where both are integers, it would perform integer division. So I need to cast one of them to a float or double to get a floating point result. So perhaps (double)t / n.

So putting it all together :

Read n using scanf. Then loop from 1 to n, check if each i is odd.
